## Getting Your Bearings: Moving Inside `vi`

```

    k        â†‘ move up

    j        â†“ move down
```

Try this simple exercise:

1.  Open a file:
    `vi filename.txt`
2.  Press **Esc** to ensure youâ€™re in **Normal mode**.
3.  Hold **j** to move down lines, **k** to move back up.
4.  Use **h** and **l** to move left and right through text.
5.  When ready to edit, press **i** to switch to **Insert mode**, type something, and **Esc** to return.

Youâ€™ve just mastered the first superpower: **intentional movement**.

## Understanding the Modes
`vi` works differently from normal editors. It has modes, and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s so fast once you get used to it.

* **Normal mode** â€” navigate, copy, delete, search

* **Insert mode** â€” actually type text

* **Command mode** (ex mode) â€” issue commands like :wq, :q!, or substitutions

At first, this feels strange. But soon it clicks â€” and your editing becomes intentional and efficient.

> ðŸ’¡ In vi, you never â€œjust type.â€ You â€œinteract with the system.â€

## From vi to vim and neovim
`vi` is the minimal core editor â€” guaranteed on every Unix system. But in your lab environment, youâ€™ll likely install **vim (Vi IMproved)** or **neovim**, both modern evolutions that retain the same keystrokes but add color, undo, and plugins.

`vi` â€” your bare-metal survival tool

## Essential Commands (No Panic Edition)
Open a file: 
```sh
vi filename.txt
```
Switch to Insert mode and type:

Press `i` â€” start inserting text

Press `Esc` â€” return to Normal mode

Save and quit: 
```sh
:wq
```
Quit without saving: 
```sh 
:q!
```

Search for a word: 
```sh
/foo
```
Replace all:
```sh
 :%s/old/new/g
```

Delete a line: 
```
dd
```
Undo: 
```
u
```

Paste (after copying with `yy`):
```
p
```
Donâ€™t memorize everything at once. Focus on the rhythm â€” edit, move, save, quit. The rest will come naturally.

#Why Not Just Use nano?

On a stripped-down FreeBSD jail, a Docker container, or an embedded Linux router â€” youâ€™ll almost never find it preinstalled.

`vi` is the one universal constant. It boots with the kernel. Itâ€™s part of the operating system itself.

So even if you prefer `vim`, learning `vi` is like learning the alphabet of Unix.

> If you know vi, you can fix anything â€” anywhere.

ex and sed: The Hidden Layer Beneath
Whatâ€™s happening when you type :%s/old/new/g in vi? Thatâ€™s actually the ex editor at work â€” the non-visual ancestor of vi.

You can run the same edit without opening the file using `sed`:

```sh

```

> Thatâ€™s the Unix philosophy in action:
> One idea, many tools, infinite reuse.
